Translated_Text: I came here, to this Brazilian land.
Morpheme_IDs: sere; pona; w; eepi; ne-1; sere; karaiwa; nono; pona

Primary_Text: Atï=pë, owa, sen=po jauhpï teese, Enkiman.
Translated_Text: What for? No, (= just/simply) Enkiman, my father-in-law, was here,
Comment: Naaki pronounces almost /jaupï/; he seems to be a K-Tiriyó speaker (with some influence from his H-Tiriyó environment at Missão Tiriós). He also had /au/ instead of /ao/ in /jauhpï/, unlike Asehpë; part of the dialectal variation? I bet /au/ vs. /ao/ varies according to dialect (perhaps even according to idiolect).
Morpheme_IDs: ati; peke-1; owa; seni; po; j; aohpi; t-1; w-1; ei; se-1; enkiman

Translated_Text: While I was in Surinam
Morpheme_IDs: suurinan; po; j; w-1; ei; 0-2; mahtao

Translated_Text: said Enkiman to me.
Morpheme_IDs: n; ka; ja-1; ne-4; enkiman; wii-2; ja

Primary_Text: Irëme wëe sen=pona Enkiman ijomi imoitoo=me,
Translated_Text: Then I came here to obey Enkiman's words,

Translated_Text: to here.

Translated_Text: then I stayed here, only me (= alone?).
Comment: Is there a purpose meaning in the /too=me/? -- check! (doesn't look easy).
Morpheme_IDs: ireme; seni; po; j; w-1; ei; topo-1; me; wii-2; rekene

Translated_Text: Well, my village had become bad (to live), the Bushnegros,
Comment: Wïta (15/Feb/2002) says: his old place in Surinam.
Morpheme_IDs: ma; j; pata; ri-1; wiripe; me; t-1; w-1; ei; se-1; meekoro

Translated_Text: the Bushnegros afflicted/attacked the village.
Morpheme_IDs: pata; t-1; hkerenma; se-1; meekoro; ja

Translated_Text: Then for me to stay here
Comment: What does this sentence really mean? Why /irë=npë=po=ro/ 'in what used to be there'? --check! Wïta (15/Feb/2002) : /irënpë=po=ro wï, jiwëepïhpë=po=ro wï/ = /tëewa=pa wae, Suurinan=pona=pa/ (i.e. I stayed only in my past coming...). Wïta says that the idea is that Naaki's village was attacked/destroyed/harassed, so he came to Brazil and never went back. João do Vale (15/Feb/2002)  translates /irënpë=po=ro/ as 'desde aquele vez, desde aquele tempo'. /irënpë=po/ sounds a bit more like 'in that place (where it happened), says João do Vale, but /irënpë=po=ro/ sounds more like a time expression. (cf. /po/ with months, etc.).
Morpheme_IDs: ireme; ire; npe; po; re; j; w-1; ei; topo-1; me; seni; po

Translated_Text: for me not to go back to Surinam.
Morpheme_IDs: te; sewa; pa; j; w-1; ei; topo-1; me; suurinan; pona; pa
